title: Maverick Jake Connor eager to step up to the Lions plate against New Zealand
text:

Jake Connor plans to turn on the style if he makes his expected Great Britain bow on Saturday.

The Hull centre was unlucky to miss out to Zak Hardaker in the weekend’s 14-6 Test defeat against Tonga. But a tour-ending injury to Oliver Gildart means Connor is likely to get the nod for this Saturday’s Test match against New Zealand.

It’s an opening the 25-year-old is determined to grab with both hands - and with a bit of flair thrown into the bargain.

He said: “I am gutted for Oli and it’s never nice for someone to go down for you to get a game. But we’re all world class players and if I get the opportunity I will take it and I will be so proud to play.”

(Image: Getty Images)

Connor made a brilliant try-scoring start to his England career in last year’s 36-18 mid-season win over New Zealand in Denver. He’s scored a further three tries in his four England starts since then and would love to increase his international tally in Auckland on Saturday.

He said: “If I get the opportunity to try something special I am going to try it 10 times out of 10. I like to be skilful, doing the extraordinary stuff and making things look exciting. I like to create my own playbook, my own style.

“The maverick stuff comes to me really easy and I honestly don’t know how. I surprised myself when I knew I could do things with the ball. It’s just instinct. Everyone has got their attributes and you play as you normally play but you’ve got to make sure it comes off because if not Wayne will be down your throat.”

(Image: Getty Images)

Wayne Bennett has copped some flak for picking six half-backs and only one specialist centre in Gildart, who is now ruled out. But Connor, who regularly plays centre for Hull even though he prefers half-back, said the squad have complete faith in Bennett’s methods.

He said: “It is kind of weird trying to say why he’s so good and I don't know how to explain it. I don't know if it's because you're that scared of messing up in a game. In video sessions he can be pretty brutal.

“But his honesty is a good trait. You know if he gives it to you, you really don't want to mess up again.”

Connor started all three games against New Zealand last autumn and Kiwis coach Michael Maguire said they need to be ready for him.

The former Wigan boss said: “He is a strong player. He grabbed a couple of tries so I remember him well and truly. We will look at how we shut him down.”
description: Hull FC utility in line for a centre spot after Oliver Gildart’s tour ended by shoulder injury
